descriptionHTML:
Endometrial cancer refers to a type of cancer in the womb lining.

Women with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch Syndrome, who are at higher risk for endometrial cancer, may consider annual screening via **pelvic ultrasound**, starting between the ages of 30 and 35.

Gastric cancer refers to cancers that occur in the stomach.

Individuals with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch Syndrome, who are at higher risk for gastric cancer, may benefit from screening with **oesophago-gastro duodenoscopy (OGD)**, starting from age 30 to 35 years. A frequency of 2 to 3 years is recommended, based on the individual's risk factors.

High-risk individuals should perform either a **hepatobiliary system ultrasound (US HBS)** or a **Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP) test** on a six-monthly basis. There is no definite recommended age to start surveillance although local (Singapore) statistics show that liver cancer incidence starts to increase from the 40 to 49 age group.

High-risk individuals aged between 55 to 74 can perform **low-dose CT screening** on an annual basis. But this should be balanced with the unnecessary exposure to radiation, financial costs of CT screening, and a high rate of false positive findings.

descriptionHTML:
Nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC) may also be referred to as nose cancer.

High-risk individuals can perform a **tumor marker test for NPC (EBV-EA-EBNA-1)** and a **nasopharyngoscopy**. The tumor marker test alone without the endoscopy is not recommended.

Carriers of BRCA1, BRCA2, or PALB2 mutations may be at higher risk of ovarian cancer and can consider a **transvaginal pelvic ultrasound**. However, it can result in unnecessary surgeries with no clear mortality benefit.
riskGroups: Carriers of BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2, or other high-risk gene mutations

descriptionHTML: Men who are between 50 to 70 years of age, with an estimated life expectancy of more than 10 years, may be offered screening with the **prostate-specific antigen (PSA) tumor marker**, after a discussion of both the potential benefits and harms associated with prostate cancer screening.
riskGroups: First-degree relative with prostate cancer before age 65 years

descriptionHTML:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) refers to an enlargement of the abdominal aorta, the main blood vessel carrying blood from the heart to the abdomen. An aneurysm can be life-threatening if it ruptures.

High-risk individuals can perform a screening with **abdominal ultrasound**.
riskGroups: Men aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked

descriptionHTML:
A cerebral aneurysm refers to an enlargement of a blood vessel in the brain. A ruptured cerebral aneurysm can cause life-threatening conditions such as a stroke.

High-risk individuals can perform a screening via a **brain MRI**.
riskGroups: Two or more first-degree relatives with intracranial aneurysms

descriptionHTML:
Coronary heart disease or coronary artery disease (CAD) refers to damage or blockage to the heart's blood vessels, often due to the build-up of fats and cholestrol. This in turn increases the risk of a heart attack.

High-risk individuals may wish to perform any of the following screenings after a discussion of both the potential benefits and harms with a healthcare professional.

- **ECG**

- **hsCRP**

- **Apolipoprotein A and B**

- **Coronary artery calcium score (CACS)**

- **Treadmill stress test**

Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) refers to the constriction or blockage of blood vessels outside the heart, often affecting the legs.

High-risk individuals can undergo the **ankle brachial index (ABI)**, a simple non-invasive test.
riskGroups: Aged 50 to 70 years with both high blood pressure and high cholestrol

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML:
Chlamydia and gonorrhoea are both sexually transmitted infections caused by different bacteria.

High-risk individuals can undergo the **urine PCR test** or a **cervical or urethral swab for PCR**.

Hepatitis B is a viral infection that affects the liver. It is commonly transmitted via exposure to body fluids, including sexual contact or blood.

High-risk individuals can perform the **Hepatitis B screen**.

All pregnant women should be tested for Hepatitis B during early antenatal visit. There is good evidence that universal prenatal screening for HBV infection substantially reduces prenatal transmission of HBV and the subsequent development of chronic HBV infection.
riskGroups: Travelers from countries where Hepatitis B is endemic
Potential exposure via infected blood, sexual activity, or other body fluid

descriptionHTML:
Hepatitis C is a viral infection that affects the liver. It is primarily transmitted via exposure to infected blood.

High-risk individuals can perform the **Hepatitis C screen**.
riskGroups: Travelers from countries where Hepatitis C is endemic

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a virus that affects the immune system and makes it harder to combat other diseases.

High-risk individuals can perform the **HIV screen**. All pregnant women should be tested for HIV, since steps can be taken to prevent viral spread to the unborn baby and during delivery.
riskGroups: Potential exposure via blood, sexual activity, or other body fluid

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML:
Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection that can eventually result in damage to multiple organs.

High-risk individuals can perform the **syphilis enzyme immunoassay** or other tests such as **TPPA** or **TPHA**. All pregnant women are recommended to screen for syphilis due to the high risk of infant morbidity and mortality.

Tuberculosis is an airborne infectious disease that can be spread when patients cough or sneeze.

Individuals with close contact to existing patients can perform the **Mantoux test** or a **chest X-ray**.
riskGroups: Close contacts of infectious tuberculosis patients

descriptionHTML:
Anaemia is a condition where the blood lacks sufficient healthy red blood cells and hemoglobin to carry oxygen throughout the body.

Screening is recommended for all pregnant women because anaemia increases the risk of a premature birth, as well as the likelihood of a low birth weight baby and postpartum depression. Anaemia can be screened via the **a full blood count test**.

Kidneys help to filter waste and excess fluid from the blood. Kidney disorders can lead to excess build up of waste and fluid in the body.

For diabetic patients, screening for albuminuria, a type of kidney disorder, should be done annually after the diagnosis of diabetes (after 5 years for Type 1, immediately for Type 2), via the **urine test for microalbumin/creatinine ratio**.

Other individuals at risk of kidney disease should also undergo **kidney function tests** or **urine analysis**.
riskGroups: Aged 50 years and older who smoke

descriptionHTML:
Osteoporosis is a condition where bones become increasingly weak and brittle. Post-menopausal white and Asian women are typically at the highest risk.

For Asian females, the [Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool (OSTA)](https://www.ttsh.com.sg/Patients-and-Visitors/Pages/Find-Conditions-and-Treatments-Details.aspx?condition=Osteoporosis-Self-Assessment-Tool-for-Asians-OSTA) for postmenopausal Asian women should be used as a risk assessment tool first before deciding on whether a **bone mass density (BMD) measurement** or **DEXA scan** should be offered.
riskGroups: Postmenopausal Asian women with a high score for the OSTA

descriptionHTML:
The thyroid gland helps to regulate body functions by producing hormones. A thyroid disorder can affect other body functions.

High-risk individuals can perform the **thyroid function test (TFT)**.

Additionally, for obese individuals, hypothyroidism may be a potential cause.

Pregnant women who have diabetes or adrenal disease may develop goitre (enlarged thyroid) during pregnancy, potentially causing mental retardation in the infant. TFT should be performed once early on during pregnancy.
riskGroups: Pregnancy with diabetes or adrenal disease

descriptionHTML:
Diabetic retinopathy refers to vision loss when high blood sugar causes damage to blood vessels in the eyes.

All patients diagnosed with diabetes require **regular visual acuity assessment and eye examinations** by trained personnel to screen for diabetic retinopathy. Type 1 diabetic patients should be examined 3 to 5 years after diagnosis of diabetes, and at least once yearly subsequently. Type 2 diabetic patients should have an ocular assessment at the time of diagnosis and at least once yearly subsequently.
